abstractText: The exceptionally high positive charge of the histones, concentrated in the Nand C-terminal tails, is believed to contribute to the stability of the nucleosome by neutralizing the negative charge of the nucleosomal DNA. We find, on the contrary, that the high positive charge contributes to instability, performing an essential function in chromatin remodeling. We show that the tails are required for removal of the histone octamer by the RSC chromatin remodeling complex, and this function is not due to direct RSC–tail interaction. We also show that the tails are required for histone octamer transfer from nucleosomes to DNA, and this activity of the tails is a consequence of their positive charge. Thus, the histone tails, intrinsically disordered protein regions, perform a critical role in chromatin structure and transcription, unrelated to their well-known role in regulation through posttranscriptional modification.

sections.text: The exceptionally high positive charge of the histones, concentrated in the N- and C-terminal tails, is believed to contribute to the stability of the nucleosome by neutralizing the negative charge of the nucleosomal DNA. We find, on the contrary, that the high positive charge contributes to instability, performing an essential function in chromatin remodeling. We show that the tails are required for removal of the histone octamer by the RSC chromatin remodeling complex, and this function is not due to direct RSC–tail interaction. We also show that the tails are required for histone octamer transfer from nucleosomes to DNA, and this activity of the tails is a consequence of their positive charge. Thus, the histone tails, intrinsically disordered protein regions, perform a critical role in chromatin structure and transcription, unrelated to their well-known role in regulation through posttranscriptional modification.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Histones have a bipartite structure, with a globular region, responsible for coiling DNA in a ‘core’ nucleosome, and disordered amino- and carboxy-terminal ‘tails’, which protrude from the core nucleosome into solution. Although commonly viewed as DNA packaging proteins, histones serve primarily for the purpose of transcription control (1). The core nucleosome is a general repressor, preventing all transcription except that brought about by positive regulatory mechanisms. The tails are subject to extensive posttranslational modification, which modulates the state of transcriptional activity through both positive and negative regulatory mechanisms.
The histones are highly positively charged, with abundant lysine and arginine residues, about two-thirds of which are concentrated in the tails. The most common posttranslational modifications are acetylation and methylation of the lysine residues. About one-third of the lysine residues are modified in some chromosomal locations at some time, but not all at the same time, so the effect of modification on positive charge is small. With most of the histone positive charge retained at all times, there must be an-
other role of the positive charge in chromosome structure and function. It is widely believed that the positive charge contributes to the stability of the nucleosome through interaction with the negatively charged DNA phosphates. The X-ray crystal structure of the core nucleosome has shown, however, that the histones interact with DNA primarily through hydrogen bonding of amino acid side chains and main chain amide moieties with the DNA phosphates, and nonpolar contacts of side chains with deoxyribose (2). The structure reveals that 6 of 29 arginine residues in the core region and 4 of 22 arginine residues in the tails form salt links to DNA phosphates, and none of the nearly 60 lysine residues in the core and tail regions form such contacts. So, 41 arginine and ∼40 lysine residues must perform a function unrelated to nucleosome structure or gene regulation through posttranslational modification. What purpose can be served by some 80 positively charged residues?
We report here on a role of the great abundance of positive charge in the histone tails. The role is counterintuitive, as we find that the tails do not stabilize the core nucleosome. Rather, they participate in nucleosome disruption, through removal of the histone octamer. This role is fundamental, as it likely gave rise to the evolution of the tails for purposes of functional activity.

sections.heading: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sections.text:
Nucleosomes were assembled with rat liver histones (3), or assembled with recombinant yeast histones, with the use of 160 bp DNA labeled with 32P at one 5′-end by PCR. RSC and NAP1 were prepared as described (4,5). Nucleosome disassembly reactions contained nucleosomes (1 ng DNA), RSC (115 ng), NAP1 (240 ng), 0.5 mM ATP, 15 mM HEPES (pH 8.0), 15 mM potassium acetate, 3 mM MgCl2 and 0.1 mg/ml BSA, in a total volume of 10 l. Following incubation at 30◦C for the times indicated, 0.8 mg of salmon sperm DNA was added to disrupt RSC– nucleosome complexes, and reaction products were separated by electrophoresis in 3.2% polyacrylamide gel (19:1 acrylamide:bisacrylamide) in TE. Optical densities were integrated over bands in phosphorimager scans for calculations of nucleosome disassembly rates. All experiments were repeated three or more times, with standard deviations indicated where appropriate.

sections.heading: Nucleosomes (rat liver histones)
sections.text: A 160 bp fragment of Xenopus 5S gene DNA, 5′-end labeled with -32P-ATP and polynucleotide kinase, or internally labeled by DNA synthesis with -32P-nucleoside triphosphate (16 l of 85 ng/ml), was combined with 11.5 l of 2.5 mg/ml rat liver chromatin (depleted of histone H1 by filtration through Sepharose 4B in 0.45 M NaCl), 19 l of 5 M NaCl, 0.5 l of 0.1 M NaHSO3 and 4.3 l H2O. The mixture was diluted with 33, 41.8 and 208 l of 25 mM HEPES (pH 7.4) and 1 mM NaHSO3, with incubation for 10 min at 30◦C after each dilution, followed by sedimentation in a 5–30% maltose gradient (11 ml) containing 25 mM HEPES (pH 7.4), 0.2 mg/ml BSA, 10 mM NaHSO3 and 1 mM EDTA in a Thermo Scientific TH-641 rotor at 35 000 rpm for 16 h.

sections.heading: Nucleosomes (yeast histones)
sections.text:
Yeast histone genes in pET vectors (gift of Bradley Cairns, University of Utah) were introduced in BL21CodonPlus(DE3)-RIPL competent Escherichia coli cells (Agilent, cat. no. 230280), grown (1 l) to an OD600 of 0.8, induced with 0.2 M IPTG at 37◦C for 2 h (H3 and H4) and 3 h (H2A and H2B), harvested, washed with water and frozen. Pellets (∼8 g) were suspended in 40 ml of 7 M guanidine, 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 5 mM dithiothreitol, 1 mM EDTA and protease inhibitors (2 mM pepstatin A, 0.6 mM leupeptin, 2 mM benzamidine, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride), sonicated (Misonix Sonicator, amplitude 40) on ice for three periods of 10 s, with cooling periods of 90 s in between, and centrifuged in a Beckman 45 Ti rotor at 42 000 rpm for 45 min. The supernatant (∼55 ml) was loaded on a Sephadex G-25 column (275 ml) in SAU 250 buffer [40 mM sodium acetate (pH 5.2), 7 M urea, 1 mM EDTA, 10 mM lysine, 250 mM NaCl, 2.5 mM dithiothreitol and protease inhibitors], followed by 250 ml of 6 M guanidine and 500 ml of H2O. Pooled protein fractions were passed through a Q Sepharose Fast Flow column (20 ml; GE Healthcare Life Sciences) in SAU 250 buffer and pooled protein fractions were applied to a HiTrap SP column (5 ml; GE Healthcare Life Sciences) in SAU 250 buffer, washed with SAU 300 buffer and eluted with a gradient of SAU 300–600 buffer. Peak histone fractions were concentrated with a Vivaspin 6 Centrifugal Concentrator (Vivaspin Products) at 4000 rpm in a clinical centrifuge to a concentration of 3.4 mg/ml, dialyzed against H2O and lyophilized.
Each lyophilized yeast histone (1 mg) dissolved in 400 l of 7 M guanidine, 20 mM Tris (pH 7.5) and 10 mM dithiothreitol, during 30 min at room temperature. Concentrations were determined from A280 values, and equimolar amounts of the four histones were combined, dialyzed in SnakeSkin dialysis tubing, 7K MWCO (Thermo Fisher Scientific, cat. no. 68100) three times against 1 l of 2 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.5), 1 mM EDTA and 15 mM -mercaptoethanol, clarified in a microfuge at 14 000 rpm for 5 min at 4◦C, filtered through a Superdex 200 Increase 10/300 GL column (GE Healthcare Life Sciences) in 2 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.5), 1 mM EDTA and 15 mM - mercaptoethanol, concentrated in a Vivaspin 2 Centrifugal Concentrator to 0.88 mg/ml and adjusted by the addition of 100% glycerol to a final concentration of 10%.
The resulting histone octamer preparation (4.99 ml of 1.56 mg/ml in 1.6 M NaCl) was mixed with 8.4 ml of 32Plabeled DNA (835 ng/ l, see above), 6.4 ml of 5 M NaCl and 0.2 ml H2O, pipetted into a Pierce Slide-A-Lyzer MINI Dialysis Unit (Thermo Scientific, cat. no. 69850), placed in an Econo-Column (Bio-Rad) with 500 ml of 2 M KCl, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.5) and 1 mM EDTA, followed by 1.5 l of 0.25 M KCl, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.5) and 1 mM EDTA at 1 ml/min, and dialyzed against 500 ml of the same buffer for 2 h. The dialysate was sedimented in a 5–30% maltose gradient in 25 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 0.1 mg/ml BSA, 10 mM NaHSO3 and 1 mM EDTA in a Beckman SW 60 Ti rotor at 55 000 rpm for 6 h.

sections.heading: RSC preparation
sections.text:
A Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain bearing a TAP tag on the Rsc2 subunit was grown to late log phase, and the cell pellet was suspended in an equal volume of lysis buffer [0.4 M HEPES (pH 7.4), 4 mM EDTA, 5 mM dithiothreitol, protease inhibitors at twice the concentrations listed above, 20% glycerol], frozen, thawed and centrifuged in a Beckman J-LITE Fixed-Angle Aluminum JLA 8.1000 rotor at 6000 rpm for 20 min. The cells were resuspended in an equal volume of 0.5× lysis buffer and disrupted in a DYNO-MILL, followed by PEI precipitation (adjusted to 200 mM ammonium sulfate, adjusted to a final concentration of 0.35% PEI by the addition of 5% PEI, centrifuged in a Beckman JA-10 Fixed-Angle rotor at 10 000 rpm for 45 min) and ammonium sulfate precipitation [addition of an equal volume of saturated ammonium sulfate to the PEI supernatant during 10 min with stirring, a further 45 min of stirring and centrifugation in the Beckman JLA 8.1000 rotor (see above) at 8000 rpm for 30 min]. The ammonium sulfate precipitate was dissolved in sufficient 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.4), 0.2 mM EDTA, 5% glycerol and protease inhibitors to reduce the conductivity lower than that of 500 mM ammonium sulfate, applied to a column of IgG Sepharose 6 Fast Flow (GE Healthcare, cat. no. 17-0969-01) in 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.4), 200 mM ammonium sulfate, 2 mM EDTA and 5% glycerol, washed with 10 column volumes of the same buffer containing 2 mM dithiothreitol and 2× protease inhibitors, washed with 10 column volumes of 50 mM RSC buffer [10 mM Tris (pH 7.4), 50 mM potassium acetate, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM dithiothreitol, 0.01% NP-40] and eluted by incubation with 1.5 column volumes of TEV protease in 50 mM RSC buffer overnight at 4◦C. RSC fractions were applied to a UNO Q1 column (20 ml, Bio-Rad) in 50 mM RSC buffer, washed with 100 mM RSC buffer and eluted with a gradient of 0.1–1 M RSC buffer.
SAGA was prepared by a similar procedure from an S. cerevisiae strain bearing a TAP tag on Spt7.

sections.heading: RESULTS
sections.text:
Histone tails destabilize the nucleosome
It was previously shown that the histone octamer dissociates from nucleosomal DNA at concentrations below ∼10 nM in the presence of 50–150 mM NaCl (6,7). Dissociation is irreversible, because histone octamers further dissociate to H2A–H2B dimers and H3–H4 tetramers. We confirmed this result with the use of nucleosomes assembled with rat liver histones on sea urchin 5S ribosomal DNA, commonly employed as a nucleosome positioning sequence (Figure 1A and B, lanes 16–20). Remarkably, following removal of the tails by digestion with trypsin (resulting in an electromobility shift of the nucleosomes, due to the increase in net negative charge, shown in Figure 1A and B, lanes 1–10, and documented by SDS-PAGE in Supplementary Figure S1), there was no dissociation at all (Figure 1A and B, lanes 6–10). Evidently, the histone tails contribute to instability of the nucleosome at high dilution in 50–150 mM NaCl. By other measures, the nucleosome was unaffected by the removal of the tails. For example, nucleosomes formed with histones possessing or lacking the tails exhibited nearly identical profiles of salt-induced dissociation, with midpoints at ∼1.13 and ∼1.05 M NaCl, respectively (8). Similarly, removal of histone tails caused only a slight increase in accessibility of
DNA near the ends of the nucleosome to digestion by various DNases (9).
It was suggested that the instability of the nucleosome at low concentration might play a role in the function of the nucleosome in vivo (6,7). The possibility was raised of kinetic rather than equilibrium control of nucleosome dynamics. We note, however, that the evidence for instability was obtained under nonphysiological conditions. In particular, dissociation was observed in the absence of polyvalent cations, essential for the stability of many protein–nucleic acid complexes. Millimolar concentrations of Mg2+ and of polyamines occur in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells (10,11). We found no dissociation of nucleosomes, with or without tails, during prolonged incubation at high dilution in 150 mM NaCl in the presence of 3 mM Mg2+ (Figure 1A and B, lanes 1–5 and 11–15). Evidently, nucleosomes are stable under physiological conditions, and dissociation must be brought about by the actions of remodelers and other molecules.
Histone transfer by RSC to a chaperone requires histone tails
RSC, an abundant, conserved chromatin remodeling complex, transfers histones from nucleosomes to the Nap1 chaperone protein, with the release of naked DNA (12). Under the conditions employed here, the reaction was essentially complete after 30 min. Following trypsin treatment and re-isolation of nucleosomes, the reaction failed to occur (Figure 2A and B). RSC activity was evidently abolished by removal of the histone tails.
Inasmuch as Nap1 interacts with H3 and H4 tails (13), the inhibition of histone transfer upon the removal of tails might reflect a loss of chaperone interaction rather than abrogation of RSC activity. This possibility was investigated by removal of H2A and H2B tails. Nucleosomes were assembled with a set of recombinant yeast histones comprising tailless H2A and H2B and wild-type H3 and

Similarly, histone transfer was diminished by deletion of either the H3 or H4 tail, and to a greater extent by the removal of both tails (Figure 2D). We conclude that RSC activity requires histone tails, and that the requirement is not limited to any one of them, but rather depends on all.
Acetylation of histone tails inhibits the transfer of histones by RSC to Nap1 (14), raising the possibility that RSC–tail interaction is involved in histone transfer and is the reason why tailless histones are not transferred. RSC– nucleosome interaction may be assessed by electromobility shift analysis (15). Dissociation constants may be determined from slopes and intercepts of Scatchard plots. The slopes for nucleosomes with and without tails were within 15% of one another, and the intercepts within a factor of 1.5 of one another, with average Kd values of 2.4 × 10−9 for nucleosomes with tails and 2.7 × 10−9 for nucleosomes without tails (Supplementary Figure S2A and B). The standard errors in this experiment were much higher than those in others, due perhaps to variation in electrophoretic behavior of the large macromolecular complexes, so the Kd values are only approximate. It nevertheless appears that the affinity of RSC for the nucleosome is high, and little affected by the removal of histone tails.
Histone octamers are transferred to DNA, and histone tails are required
The role of the histone tails in histone octamer transfer is not limited to the activities of chromatin remodeling complexes. We found that nucleosomes dissociate rapidly in the presence of excess naked DNA (Figure 3A and B), whereas tailless nucleosomes are unaffected (Figure 3C and D). Similar results were obtained for chromatin as for isolated nucleosomes (Supplementary Figure S3). The octamer appears to be transferred intact to naked DNA, rather than sequentially as H2A–H2B dimers and H3–H4 tetramer, because no intermediates are observed (the ratio of the octamer nucleosome to a presumptive hexamer nucleosome remains constant throughout the reaction). Loss of histones from tailless nucleosomes only occurred at ionic strengths of 0.4 M and above (Figure 3C and D), at which point histone octamers are known to dissociate even in the absence of additional DNA.
The role of individual tails in histone transfer to DNA was investigated with nucleosomes assembled from yeast histones lacking one or more tails. Deletion of any one of the four tails was detrimental to transfer (Figure 3E and F). The effect of deletion was about the same for all tails. Evidently, all tails participate, more or less equally, in the histone transfer process.

Role of positive charge in histone transfer
Because the effect of deletion of the histone tails is incremental, and similar for all tails, there must be a common feature of all the tails that is important for histone transfer. The likely feature is net positive charge. All four histone tails contain ∼10 lysine and arginine residues, and no acidic residues (except for one aspartic acid in the H2B tail). We tested the role of positive charge by acetylation of lysine residues with acetic anhydride (documented by mass spectrometry; Supplementary Materials), a method commonly employed to neutralize the lysine positive charge. The result was a marked reduction in the rate of histone transfer to DNA (Table 1), comparable to that observed upon removal of the tails from two of the histones (Figure 2). Histone charge evidently plays an important role in histone octamer transfer.

sections.heading: DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Why does a nucleosome bear over 100 positive charges unrelated to the structure of the core particle and unrelated to the role of lysine posttranslational modification in gene regulation? An answer we find relates to the role of the core particle in transcriptional activity. The core particle must be extraordinarily stable to fulfill its role as a general transcription inhibitor, and yet must be capable of rapid dissociation to allow transcription initiation when and where required. The abundance of positive charge in the tails may facilitate dissociation.
The positively charged tails may interact with negatively charged nucleosomal DNA to stabilize a partially dissociated state. Histone octamer transfer to naked DNA may be enhanced in this way, but if there were no other effects of
the tails, then the rate of transfer would be linearly dependent on the concentration of naked DNA. Rather, the effect is saturable, tending to a limit as the concentration of naked DNA is raised. Transfer evidently proceeds through an intermediate nucleosome:naked DNA complex, which is likely stabilized by interaction of the tails with naked DNA. Similarly, we suggest that histone octamer transfer by RSC to Nap1 occurs through an intermediate nucleosome:Nap1 complex, stabilized by interaction of the positively charged tails with negatively charged Nap1 (pI 4.7). Indeed, an Xray crystal structure of Nap1 has revealed a concentration of negative charge in a region suggested to be involved in histone tail–Nap1 interaction (16).
There is precedent for a role of the tails in nucleosome– DNA interaction (17,18). Both theoretical and experimental studies have indicated a role of the tails in chromatin condensation (19–21). For example, native chromatin fibers precipitate at 2 mM MgCl2, whereas tailless fibers do not precipitate at any concentration tested up to 50 mM MgCl2 (22). Fibers containing one or some combination of tails precipitated at intermediate MgCl2 concentrations. It was concluded that the histone tails contributed ‘additively and independently’ to interfiber interaction. The abundant positive charge of the tails may therefore perform at least two roles, contributing to histone octamer transfer and also to chromosome condensation.
Theoretical studies have indicated roles of the tails in both stabilization and destabilization of the nucleosome (19,23–25), and in particular, destabilization by partial unwrapping of nucleosomal DNA. Partial unwrapping may play a role in chromatin remodeling, inasmuch as remodelers such as SWI/SNF complex and RSC function by translocating DNA across the surface of the nucleosome. Translocation occurs by the formation of a bulge or loop of ∼10 bp, which passes through the nucleosome in a process referred to as reptation (26). There is experimental evidence for this mechanism (27) and theoretical support for a role of the tails in the process (28–30). Removal of histone tails has been shown to impair remodeling by SWI/SNF (31), and the tails may contribute in this manner to histone transfer by RSC, as well as through interaction with the target of transfer, Nap1 or DNA.
Destabilization of the nucleosome by the histone tails is counterintuitive. It is commonly believed that the nucleosome is stabilized by electrostatic interaction of the positively charged histones with the negatively charged DNA. In humans, the globular region of the histone octamer has a net charge of +58, the tails have a charge of +98 and the DNA has a charge of −294 (32). So, the globular region neutralizes only 20% of the negative charge of DNA in the ‘core’ nucleosome. The major part of the histone positive charge resides in the tails outside of the core nucleosome. Charge–charge interactions contribute little to the stability of the ‘core’ nucleosome. Rather, hydrogen binding and nonpolar interactions play a major role, as mentioned above. The extraordinarily high affinity of the histone octamer for DNA is due to the multiplicity of such interactions. The concentration of positive charge in the histone tails plays an altogether different role.
It is noteworthy that the histone tails do not contribute significantly to the affinity of RSC–nucleosome interaction.

Although RSC contains protein domains for interaction with modified lysine residues in the tails, RSC binds primarily to the core nucleosome. Recent cryogenic electron microscopy studies confirm this interaction (33). Abundant positive charge of lysine and arginine residues in the tails drives chromatin remodeling. This role is general, applicable not only to remodeling by RSC but also to nucleosome disruption by other agents, such as small molecules that bind only to DNA and not to modified or unmodified tail residues (34). This role of the tails is fundamental, as the occurrence of lysine residues in the tails must have preceded their function as targets of posttranslational modification. The tails appear to have evolved in parallel with the core nucleosome, as archaea, which possess only two histones and no tails, form chromatin that can be disrupted by transcription factors with no requirement for remodeling (35–37). The acquisition of additional histones to form a much more stable nucleosome created a requirement for remodeling and for the histone tails to assist in the process.
Posttranslational modifications of lysine residues in the histone tails modulate a wide range of genomic transactions. However, only about a quarter of all positively charged residues in the tails are subject to modification, which begs the question of the role of positive charge in the tails. One role, mentioned above, is for electrostatic interactions to enable chromosome condensation. Our findings demonstrate another important role, the catalysis of chromatin remodeling.

title: Role of the histone tails in histone octamer transfer
